data.title: CapitaLand China Trust Likely Weighed by Weak Business Sentiment — Market Talk
data.description: CapitaLand China Trust's results could continue to be weighed by persistently weak business sentiment in the world's second-largest economy, OCBC Investment Research's Ada Lim says in a note. The China-focused REIT's revenue and net property income declined in 3Q, and rents were renewed at lower rates across retail, business-park and logistics-park assets, she notes. While the Singapore-listed REIT's manager could consider unit buybacks using the net proceeds from a recent divestment, Lim thinks the window of opportunity has narrowed due the REIT's unit-price recovery this year. OCBC raises its 2026 distribution-per-unit estimate by 2.4%, leading to a higher fair-value estimate of S$0.74 versus S$0.705 previously. The bank maintains its hold rating, citing a poor rent-renewal outlook and foreign-exchange headwinds. Units rise 1.3% to S$0.80. (megan.cheah@wsj.com)

data.title: Maruti Suzuki India second quarter profit misses estimates
data.description:
Maruti Suzuki , India's largest carmaker, reported second-quarter profit below estimates on Friday as higher input costs and expenses weighed on margins.

The 'Brezza' SUV manufacturer's standalone profit rose 7.3% to 32.9 billion indian rupees ($374.31 million) in July-September, falling short of analysts' expectations of 35.93 billion rupees, according to data compiled by LSEG.

($1 = 87.8950 Indian rupees)

data.title: Gilt Yields Rise as Rate-Cut Expectations Decline After Fed Meeting — Market Talk
data.description: Yields on U.K. government bonds climb, tracking U.S. and eurozone peers, as investors lower expectations of major central banks cutting interest rates in the coming months. This comes after the U.S. Federal Reserve cut interest rates Wednesday but said rates wouldn't necessarily fall in December. Meanwhile, the European Central Bank held rates steady Thursday and pointed to a resilient economy. As U.S. and eurozone rate-cut expectations have fallen, so U.K. rate-cut expectations have also slipped. Money markets price a 62% chance of the Bank of England cutting rates by the end of 2025, down from 72% a week ago, LSEG data show. Ten-year gilt yields climb 2.2 basis points to 4.430%, Tradeweb data show. (miriam.mukuru@wsj.com)

data.title: Mitsubishi Chemical's sales fall despite more than doubling of profit, cuts forecast expectations
data.description:
Mitsubishi Chemical Group Corp. said its net profit more than doubled to Yen110.1 billion ($716.5 million) in the fiscal six months ended Sept. 30, compared with a profit of Yen40.9 billion a year earlier, as per Chemweek.

However, the company did not disclose specific reasons for the profit increase. Sales for the company fell 10.5% year over year to Yen1.7 trillion, and operating profit slipped 19.6% to Yen86.4 billion.The interim consolidated accounting period was marked by a slowing economic environment, influenced by the widespread effects of the US trade policy. While the company benefited from economic stimulus measures in China and aggressive fiscal spending in certain European nations, overall growth remained sluggish, the company said.Mitsubishi Chemical has revised its forecast for the fiscal year ending March 31, 2026. The company now anticipates a net profit of Yen125 billion, down from a previous projection of Yen145 billion. Sales expectations have been adjusted to Yen3.7 trillion from an earlier estimate of ?3.6 trillion, while the forecast for operating income has been lowered to Yen176 billion, compared to the prior estimate of ?202 billion. The anticipated decline in income is attributed to a reduction in price gaps and decreased sales volumes, particularly in the methyl methacrylate (MMA) and derivatives segment, as well as in the basic materials and polymers segment.In the specialty materials segment, revenue decreased by 3.2% year over year to Yen520.6 billion. However, core operating income rose by 36.3% to Yen33.4 billion, driven by increased sales volumes from recovering demand for high-performance engineering plastics and the effects of production rationalization. The segment also benefited from improved selling prices in semiconductor-related businesses, despite facing challenges in the carbon fiber and composite sectors due to inflation-related cost increases.Conversely, the advanced films and polymers sector experienced a decline in sales revenue, primarily due to inventory adjustments by customers and foreign exchange impacts. The advanced solutions segment also reported decreased revenue, largely due to reduced demand for electric vehicle applications in Europe and the US and lower sales volumes of printing materials resulting from US tariffs.In the MMA and derivatives segment, revenue declined by 20.6% year over year to Yen178 billion, with core operating income down by 84% to Yen4.2 billion. The decline was driven by falling market prices for MMA and a decrease in sales volume due to diminished demand. Revenue from the coatings and additives sector also experienced a decline. The drop was attributed to a significant decrease in sales volume, largely resulting from reduced demand for paints, adhesives, inks and other related applications.Mitsubishi Chemical’s basic materials and polymers division saw a sales drop of 28% year over year to Yen386.4 billion. However, core operating losses in this division narrowed from Yen12 billion to Yen2.7 billion. The improvement in operating income can be attributed to several factors, including a widened price gap between raw materials and finished products, particularly in the polyolefins segment. Additionally, the impact of scheduled maintenance on ethylene production facilities was less severe than anticipated. The division also benefited from enhanced inventory valuation gains and losses within the carbon products business, alongside effective cost reduction efforts.However, the overall sales revenue decline was primarily driven by several challenges. The transfer of shares of a specified subsidiary in the purified terephthalic acid business significantly impacted revenue. Furthermore, the division experienced a drop in selling prices, which correlated with lower raw material prices and adverse foreign exchange impacts.In the carbon products segment, revenue also suffered due to the transfer of shares of a specified subsidiary in the cokes business. Sales volumes decreased because of reduced cokes production capacity, while selling prices for cokes fell in line with declining raw material prices and sluggish market demand.The industrial gases segment, managed by Nippon Sanso Holdings Group, reported a modest 1.1% increase in sales to Yen647 billion, although core operating income dipped by 1.3% to Yen93 billion. The increase in sales was attributed to the acquisition and consolidation of the industrial gas business in Australia and New Zealand, alongside effective price management efforts. However, overall demand remained sluggish, impacting sales volumes, particularly in Europe and the US.

mrchub.com

data.title: TT Electronics Reiterates Intention to Back Cicor's $377 Million Takeover Bid
data.description:
By Anthony O. Goriainoff

TT Electronics reiterated its support for Cicor's 287 million pound ($377.4 million) takeover bid after its largest shareholder, DBAY Advisors, said it wouldn't approve the deal, having submitted its own proposals recently.

The electrical-solutions manufacturer said Friday that DBAY had submitted three offer proposals over the past three months, the last of which was received on Oct. 7 at 130 pence a share. All three proposals, which had a number of conditions attached, were rejected by the board.

On Thursday TT said it agreed to be taken over by Swiss company Cicor Technologies in a deal offering shareholders 100 pence in cash and 0.0028 new Cicor shares.

The offer valued each TT share at 155 pence based on Cicor's share price and was a 63.5% premium to the London-listed company's closing share price of 94.80 pence Wednesday.

DBAY--which owns 16.5% of TT--subsequently said that it didn't support the bid as it was happy with the progress the company was making.

The investment company added that it wouldn't vote in favor of the deal at either the court or general meetings, which are expected to be held in December.

TT Electronics said Friday it had spoken to several shareholders, including DBAY, and welcomes their views.

"The board of TT remains focused on delivering maximum value for all shareholders and believes the Cicor offer is the best route to achieving this objective," it said.

Shares were down 2 pence, or 1.3%, at 149.80 pence in early morning European trading. They are currently up 42% over the year to date.

Write to Anthony O. Goriainoff at anthony.orunagoriainoff@dowjones.com

data.title: U.S. Futures Rise, European Stocks Drop
data.description:
U.S. futures for the S&P 500 were up 0.6% and futures for the Dow Jones Industrial Average climbed 0.1%. Changes in futures do not necessarily predict movements after the opening bell.

In Europe, the Stoxx Europe 600 dropped 0.1% in morning trading. Fuchs Pfd. rose 10.5% and Puig Brands added 9.1%. On the other hand, Scor SE lost 5.5%, and Spie slipped 4.1%. The FTSE 100 lost 0.2%. Other stocks in Europe were down as France's CAC 40 declined 0.1% and Germany's DAX fell 0.3%.

The Wall Street Journal Dollar Index rose 0.1% to 96.77.

In commodities, Brent crude fell 0.1% to $64.30 a barrel, and WTI crude fell 0.1% to $60.50 a barrel. The European benchmark price for natural gas, the Dutch futures contract TTF, was up 0.8% to 31.61 euros a megawatt hour.

The German 10-year Bund yield rose by 1 basis point to 2.663% from 2.648%, and the yield on the 10-year U.S. Treasury climbed by 2 basis points to 4.118% from 4.099%. Bond prices and yields move in opposite directions.

Stocks in Asia were mixed as Japan's Nikkei 225 index gained 2.1%, whereas Hong Kong's Hang Seng dropped 1.4%. China's benchmark Shanghai Composite dropped 0.8%.

-This article was automatically generated by MarketWatch.

Write to Barcelona Editors at barcelonaeditors@dowjones.com

Bharti Airtel Expected to Report Higher Second-Quarter Net Profit — Earnings Preview
data.description:
By Kosaku Narioka

Bharti Airtel is scheduled to report its second-quarter results on Monday. Here's what you need to know:

NET PROFIT FORECAST: Bharti Airtel's net profit is estimated to have risen 79% from a year earlier to 64.33 billion rupees, equivalent to $725.8 million, for the three months ended Sept. 30, according to a poll of analysts by Visible Alpha. That would compare with net profit of 35.93 billion rupees in the year-earlier period.

REVENUE FORECAST: Second-quarter revenue is expected to have increased 22% to 506.56 billion rupees, according to the Visible Alpha poll.

The stock has risen 30% year to date through Thursday, driven by hopes for greater earnings fueled by mobile fee increases in India.

WHAT TO WATCH:

  • Profit from its Indian mobile services rose 74% to 84.25 billion rupees in its first quarter as its customer base grew 2.3% to 362.8 million and average revenue per user increased 19% to 250 rupees a month. Investors will be focusing on any further profit growth in the company's largest segment.
  • Bharti Airtel's earnings-before-interest-and-taxes margin improved to 31.6% in its first quarter from 27.6% a year earlier. Investors will be closely watching margin trends as inflationary pressures have eased in India and elsewhere.
  • First-quarter capital expenditure dropped 15% to 83.07 billion rupees. Investors will be paying attention to the capex burden required to maintain and upgrade its vast communications network.

Write to Kosaku Narioka at kosaku.narioka@wsj.com

data.title: Uganda gives 18% higher estimate for recoverable oil reserves
data.description:
Uganda's energy minister said the East African country's recoverable oil reserves were about 18% higher than previously estimated, without giving a reason.

Minister Ruth Nankabirwa said in a post on X on Thursday that recoverable reserves were now estimated at 1.65 billion barrels, up from 1.4 billion barrels.

A spokesperson for the energy ministry did not immediately respond to a request for comment about why the estimate had risen.

Uganda discovered oil near its border with Democratic Republic of Congo nearly two decades ago, but production has been delayed by a range of factors including a lack of infrastructure.

Commercial production from fields operated by TotalEnergies and China's CNOOC is expected to start next year.

data.title: DAX at 2-Week Low
data.description:
Germany's DAX fell 0.3% to around 24,035 on Friday, a two-week low, after a week packed with central bank meetings, progress in US-China trade, and a flood of corporate and economic data.

Investors will closely watch today’s Eurozone inflation data, which could guide the ECB’s next steps.

Among stocks, top losers included Deutsche Telekom (-1.3%), Adidas (-1.3%), Hannover Ruck (-1%) and Scout24 (-0.9%).

data.title: Street View: Apple's iPhone 17 cycle has more room to run, time to fasttrack AI rollout
data.description:
** Apple CEO Tim Cook on Thursday forecast holiday quarter iPhone sales and overall revenue that surpassed Wall Street expectations, powered by orders for iPhone 17 models that the company is racing to fulfill amid continuing supply constraints

** Shares up 2% at $277.3 premarket

SOLID FY26

** Wedbush ("outperform," PT: $320) says iPhone 17 launch is off to a great start heading into the key holiday December quarter in the US and China

** Says the elephant in the room remains the invisible AI strategy, "with the biggest consumer installed base in the world of 2.4 billion iOS devices and 1.5 billion iPhones, the time is now for Apple to accelerate its AI efforts through Google in our view"

** TD Cowen ("buy," PT: $325) says higher R&D for AI is necessary for competitiveness, but a stronger FY26 growth view limits any negative operating leverage

** D.A.Davidson ("neutral," PT: $270) says growing demand for iPhone 17 is setting up a positive FY26

** Despite pockets of weakness in iPhone and China sales, firm's expanding services segment and improving margins highlight the resilience of its business model heading into 2026, says Ethan Feller, stock strategist at Zacks Investment Research

data.title: Maruti Suzuki India 2Q Rev INR423.44B Vs. INR374.49B >532500.BY
Spain's Mapfre profit jumps on strong performance worldwide
data.description:
By Mireia Merino

Spanish insurer Mapfre reported on Friday a 26.8% rise in nine-month net profit to 829 million euros ($967 million), boosted by a strong performance across its operations globally and an improved combined ratio.

The company attributed its growth to profitability across all regions and business lines, with premiums increasing 3.5% to 22.4 billion euros.

The group's non-life combined ratio - the industry's key profitability measure - improved by 2.2 percentage points to 92.6% - a favourable shift reflecting tariff adjustments and technical measures.

The increase came despite one-time costs of 79 million euros tied to a write down in Mexico and the cancellation of deferred tax assets in Italy and Germany.

The Iberia region led the insurer's profit, driven by strong motor and health insurance performance, which offset currency depreciation and high interest rates in Brazil.

In Spain and Portugal, Mapfre posted a net profit of 347 million euros, up 22.5% from 283 million euros a year ago.

Car insurance contributed 96 million euros in profit, from 89 million euros in the first half, when it switched to profit from losses after dragging the company down in the previous years.

Mapfre also said it would pay a dividend of 0.070 euro per share, slightly higher than the dividend paid a year earlier.

($1 = 0.8575 euros)

data.title: IFC approves USD100 mln financing for Paraguay low-carbon fertilizer plant
data.description: International Finance Corp.’s (IFC) board has approved up to $100 million in financing for ATOME’s $630 million low-carbon fertilizer plant in Paraguay, marking a significant step toward final investment decision (FID) for the 260,000 metric tons per year facility, as per Chemweek.The World Bank Group’s private investment arm approved the financing package combining concessional debt and project-level equity for the Villeta Project, according to a company statement. The approval comes as global fertilizer markets face supply constraints and environmental pressures, with the project positioned to serve Paraguay’s agricultural sector while reducing carbon emissions compared to conventional production methods.ATOME is targeting a final investment decision before year-end, which would trigger construction of what it describes as a landmark facility for the region’s agricultural industry.The financing approval reflects IFC’s broader climate investment strategy, with the institution committing over $9 billion in long-term climate finance during 2024. IFC currently maintains approximately $17 billion in total exposure across Latin America and the Caribbean, positioning the Villeta Project within a substantial regional portfolio focused on sustainable development.The project’s debt financing structure includes multiple development finance institutions beyond IFC, with public disclosures showing participation from the European Investment Bank, IDB Invest, Dutch development bank FMO, and the Green Climate Fund. This multilateral backing suggests strong institutional confidence in the project’s viability and development impact potential.“The IFC Board’s approval of up to US$100 million of debt and equity financing for Villeta is another strong endorsement of the Project’s maturity, bankability, and positive development impact,” said Olivier Mussat, ATOME’s chief executive officer. “This is another important step towards finalizing the US$630 million project funding as we remain focused on achieving FID before the end of the year." mrchub.com

data.title: Permanent TSB Shouldn't Sell Itself Too Soon — Market Talk
data.description: The timing for a potential sale of Permanent TSB isn't ideal, Keefe, Bruyette & Woods says in a research note. The state-backed Irish bank currently has no bidders but expects to find a buyer in the first half of 2026. "It is difficult to match up the confidence from management in the current business trends, the risk review process and the improving [return on tangible equity] outlook, with the decision from the board to start this process to sell the bank," analysts Andrew Stimpson and Fatima Ghaznavi write. While PTSB is already an attractive asset, buyers will want to know the outcome of the risk-model review, which KBW expects will vastly improve the capital ratio. Shares closed 23% higher on Thursday. (elena.vardon@wsj.com)
